Award.AwardTitle: Layout Compression for Electron-Beam Direct-Write Lithography Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: Electron-Beam Direct-Write microlithography systems use an array of electron beams to write a mask image on a photo-resist coated wafer. They are attractive for Next-Generation Lithography because they are able to produce circuits with much smaller features than conventional hotolithography systems which need expensive physical masks, but they currently have the disadvantage of being much slower than physical mask lithography systems. The objective of this project is to develop specially designed data compression algorithms for the huge electronically controlled mask images of electron-beam direct-write lithography systems in order to speed up and improve such systems. The problem of layout image compression differs from the majority of work on image compression, which targets "natural" images, because there are (1) severe constraints on the decoder, (2) complications in the extraction of patterns, and (3) special structures within layout images to be exploited.

Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit is the development of circuit layout image compression algorithms and implementations which are wellsuited to the requirements of evolving electron-beam direct-write lithography systems including existing promising massively parallel pixel projection maskless lithography systems which use various writing strategies.

Broader impacts: Microelectronic circuits directly impact the speed and efficiency of many information technology systems including signal and media processing, aerospace, and defense. The transformative nature of the project is that it addresses the critical problem of data delivery which currently limits the viability of electron-beam direct-write lithography systems and canthereby profoundly affect the future manufacturing of integrated circuits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Micro/nanolithography creates the patterns on wafers for integrated circuit manufacturing and has been the technical foundation for the success of Moore's Law, which has guided the semiconductor industry's targets for the rate of increase of components on integrated circuits for decades.  In the project "Layout Compression for Electron-Beam Direct-Write Lithography Systems," Serap Savari has been conducting research with her graduate studentsto develop specially designed data compression algorithms for the huge electronically controlled mask images found in lithography systems in order to increase the throughput of such systems.  The type of  "layout" images used in semiconductor manufacturing differs from the "natural'' images that are typically considered within image compression because of their special structure, and the constraints on processing differ as well.


She began by studying the system developed at MAPPER Lithography, which has electron beam writers positioned in a lattice formation so that each electron beam writer writes a designated block in a zig-zag order.  To handle these requirements she and her group developed the Corner2-MEB algorithm, which is suitable for MAPPER-like systems and attains a high performance.  Dr. Savari was invited to give colloquia at KLA-Tencor and at Intel on this work in 2013. Through that work she obtained an agreement of cooperation with GenISys, Inc., which works with many organizations handling various aspects of semiconductor manufacturing.
Dr. Savari next considered another trend within lithography.  Intel and some other companies are using unidirectional layouts to simplify the manufacturing of circuits.  In particular, complementary lithography is an approach for fabricating unidirectional and gridded layouts where optical lithography produces unidirectional lines at a fixed pitch and electron-beam direct-write lithography cuts those lines.  Dr. Savari studied lossless data compression for the "cut'' images.  In his pioneering paper introducing information theory Claude Shannon used the example of the constraints present in telegraphy to invent the finite-state channel as a model for transmitting one-dimensional information.  Dr. Savari showed how to use Shannon's theory to bound the information content within the "cut'' images used in complementary lithography, and there are compression schemes to approach the limits from Shannon's theory.  Dr. Savari presented this work at the 58th International Conference on Electron, Ion, and Photon Beam Technology and Nanofabrication in 2014 and published it in the Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B.


Dr. Savari and her students subsequently studied the Reflective Electron Beam Lithography (REBL) system.  They proposed several new layout image compression algorithms called  the Corner2-EPC algorithms, which are suitable for bidirectional layout images which have been processed with the commercial electron beam proximity correction software of GenISys, Inc. Their algorithms offer interesting trade-offs between compression ratios and decoding speeds.  Most of these algorithms achieve better overall performance than earlier image compression algorithms while having low decoding times and resources.  Dr. Savari presented this work at the 59th International Conference on Electron, Ion, and Photon Beam Technology and Nanofabrication in 2015 and was invited to repeat the talk at the 2015 European Mask and Lithography Conference.  She and her collaborators published the algorithms and result later that year in the Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B; this paper appeared in the "most read'' list of the Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B papers in September 2015.  


Dr. Savari and her students proceeded to consider mask-writing lithographysystems.  Single beam mask writer architectures have satisfied mask patterning requirements for decades, but there is now great interest in multibeam mask writers to handle the throughput and resolution demands arising from the needs of sub-10nm technology nodes. Future mask writers must transmit terabits of information per second and handle petabytes of data.  For the multibeam mask architectures proposed by IMS Nanofabrication and NuFlare the data being transmitted is significantly processed and modified from the initial proximity-corrected layout images, so the data compression problem for this application appears to be new.  Dr. Savari and her students examined how parallelism affects the total beam compressed data for a family of idealized multibeam architectures inspired by the IMS Nanofabrication eMET series.  Dr. Savari gave an invited presentation on these results at the 60th International Conference on Electron, Ion, and Photon Beam Technology and Nanofabrication in 2016 and discussed related results at the 2016 European Mask and Lithography Conference.  She and her students published this work in the Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B.  Based on her presentations in 2015 and 2016 at the European Mask and Lithography Conference Dr. Savari was invited in January 2017 to join the (existing) Program Committee for the 2017 European Mask and Lithography Conference; she has participated in a telephone meeting of that committee. 

Dr. Savari and her student recently proposed a new data decompression architecture which can be attached to NuFlare's deflection plate (or blanking aperture array) architecture as well as an alternate datapath architecture to reduce existing throughput bottlenecks.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2017
Modified by: Serap A Savari

Images (1 of )
  • Proposed decompression architecture assuming an k x n beam array.k parallel decoders convert the k compressed strings C1, ..., Ck to the correspondinguncompressed 10-bit symbols U1, ..., Uk and communicate them tocontrol circuits on the deflection plate.
    Currently unpublished
    Public Domain
    Serap A Savari
    Parallel data decompression architecture.
  • Datapath architecture used in multibeam mask writing systems under development.
    Currently unpublished
    Public Domain
    Serap A Savari
    Current datapath architecture.
  • A datapath architecture which uses data compression and decompression and a scanning strategy to improve the throughput of the multibeam mask writing systems under development.
    Currently unpublished
    Public Domain
    Serap A Savari
    Proposed datapath architecture.
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Micro/nanolithography creates the patterns on wafers for integrated circuit manufacturing and has been the technical foundation for the success of Moore's Law, which has guided the semiconductor industry's targets for the rate of increase of components on integrated circuits for decades. In the project "Layout Compression for Electron-Beam Direct-Write Lithography Systems," Serap Savari has been conducting research with her graduate studentsto develop specially designed data compression algorithms for the huge electronically controlled mask images found in lithography systems in order to increase the throughput of such systems. The type of "layout" images used in semiconductor manufacturing differs from the "natural'' images that are typically considered within image compression because of their special structure, and the constraints on processing differ as well. She began by studying the system developed at MAPPER Lithography, which has electron beam writers positioned in a lattice formation so that each electron beam writer writes a designated block in a zig-zag order. To handle these requirements she and her group developed the Corner2-MEB algorithm, which is suitable for MAPPER-like systems and attains a high performance. Dr. Savari was invited to give colloquia at KLA-Tencor and at Intel on this work in 2013. Through that work she obtained an agreement of cooperation with GenISys, Inc., which works with many organizations handling various aspects of semiconductor manufacturing. Dr. Savari next considered another trend within lithography. Intel and some other companies are using unidirectional layouts to simplify the manufacturing of circuits. In particular, complementary lithography is an approach for fabricating unidirectional and gridded layouts where optical lithography produces unidirectional lines at a fixed pitch and electron-beam direct-write lithography cuts those lines. Dr. Savari studied lossless data compression for the "cut'' images. In his pioneering paper introducing information theory Claude Shannon used the example of the constraints present in telegraphy to invent the finite-state channel as a model for transmitting one-dimensional information. Dr. Savari showed how to use Shannon's theory to bound the information content within the "cut'' images used in complementary lithography, and there are compression schemes to approach the limits from Shannon's theory. Dr. Savari presented this work at the 58th International Conference on Electron, Ion, and Photon Beam Technology and Nanofabrication in 2014 and published it in the Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B. Dr. Savari and her students subsequently studied the Reflective Electron Beam Lithography (REBL) system. They proposed several new layout image compression algorithms called the Corner2-EPC algorithms, which are suitable for bidirectional layout images which have been processed with the commercial electron beam proximity correction software of GenISys, Inc. Their algorithms offer interesting trade-offs between compression ratios and decoding speeds. Most of these algorithms achieve better overall performance than earlier image compression algorithms while having low decoding times and resources. Dr. Savari presented this work at the 59th International Conference on Electron, Ion, and Photon Beam Technology and Nanofabrication in 2015 and was invited to repeat the talk at the 2015 European Mask and Lithography Conference. She and her collaborators published the algorithms and result later that year in the Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B; this paper appeared in the "most read'' list of the Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B papers in September 2015. Dr. Savari and her students proceeded to consider mask-writing lithographysystems. Single beam mask writer architectures have satisfied mask patterning requirements for decades, but there is now great interest in multibeam mask writers to handle the throughput and resolution demands arising from the needs of sub-10nm technology nodes. Future mask writers must transmit terabits of information per second and handle petabytes of data. For the multibeam mask architectures proposed by IMS Nanofabrication and NuFlare the data being transmitted is significantly processed and modified from the initial proximity-corrected layout images, so the data compression problem for this application appears to be new. Dr. Savari and her students examined how parallelism affects the total beam compressed data for a family of idealized multibeam architectures inspired by the IMS Nanofabrication eMET series. Dr. Savari gave an invited presentation on these results at the 60th International Conference on Electron, Ion, and Photon Beam Technology and Nanofabrication in 2016 and discussed related results at the 2016 European Mask and Lithography Conference. She and her students published this work in the Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B. Based on her presentations in 2015 and 2016 at the European Mask and Lithography Conference Dr. Savari was invited in January 2017 to join the (existing) Program Committee for the 2017 European Mask and Lithography Conference; she has participated in a telephone meeting of that committee. Dr. Savari and her student recently proposed a new data decompression architecture which can be attached to NuFlare's deflection plate (or blanking aperture array) architecture as well as an alternate datapath architecture to reduce existing throughput bottlenecks.
